title: Great-granddad lies ‘freezing’ in street as ambulance takes two hours to arrive
text:
Terence Howard, 72, was left lying on the ground for two hours (Picture: SWNS)

A great-grandfather who fell in the street thought he was on his ‘last breath’ after having to wait more than two hours for an ambulance.

Terence Howard, 72, banged his head and broke his nose after falling when he got off a bus at Radcliffe bus station, in Greater Manchester.

Emergency services told his daughter Paula not to move him, but despite her four desperate calls to operators, his case was marked as low priority for paramedics.

An ambulance was only dispatched when the pensioner began struggling to breathe, more than two hours after his fall.

Terence said: ‘I would have died if the ambulance hadn’t come then. I was shivering, it was freezing cold, I think hypothermia would have set in if I was left there any longer.

Medics advised not to move him (Picture: SWNS)

‘When the ambulance arrived, I felt like I was on my last breath.’

The pensioner, who is diabetic, believes high blood sugar levels caused him to lose balance and fall as he exited the bus around 5pm on October 1.

A woman spotted he had fallen and alerted the bus driver, who then pulled over next to him to protect him from the wind while he waited for an ambulance.

Terence said there was ‘blood everywhere’, adding that kind strangers placed their coats on him to keep him warm.

He continued: ‘I would have been dead if people hadn’t come out and put those coats on me. It shouldn’t have taken that long for ambulance to come out.

He felt like he was on his ‘last breath’ (Picture: SWNS)

‘Once it had been dispatched, it was here in minutes. They should have sent one out earlier.’

Terence’s daughter Paula had been travelling home to Bolton when she received a call from a passerby using her dad’s phone.

But by the time she got there, emergency services had still not been dispatched to the scene and she was told on the phone paramedics in the area were ‘very busy’.

Paula said: ‘He’s a pensioner, he’s a vulnerable person, it’s shocking they didn’t consider him a priority.

‘My dad was on the concrete ground, freezing cold with some blankets from a shop over the road. There was blood everywhere and he was freezing.

The great-grandfather was kept in hospital for a week (Picture: SWNS)

‘I know hospitals are stupidly busy, but they could have got an ambulance there and he should have been prioritised.’

She added: ‘I was worried the worst would happened. I thought I was going to lose my dad. If I hadn’t told them he wasn’t breathing properly, they wouldn’t have come.’

After two hours, Terence began to feel a ‘large ball’ in the back of his throat which caused him breathing difficulties.

When Paula told the operator this, an ambulance was finally dispatched and arrived at the scene eight minutes after her call.

He was taken to hospital, where he stayed for almost a week before being released on Monday, October 7.

He has since been discharged (Picture: SWNS)

A spokesman for the North West Ambulance Service said Terence’s fall had been classed as a category three response, which means paramedics will aim to arrive within two hours.

They continued: ‘Following further calls regarding a change to the patient’s condition, the call was upgraded to a category one at 6.59pm and we arrived on scene at 7.07pm.

‘We always try to get to patients as quickly as we can but we have to prioritise those in an immediately life-threatening condition in order to get them the help they need as soon as possible.

‘We are sorry for any distress caused and would encourage the patient or a family member to contact us directly so we can discuss this with them in more detail. We sincerely hope he is recovering well.’

description: Terence Howard fell as he got off a bus at Radcliffe bus station, in Greater Manchester and waited two hours for an ambulance.
